ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about strategies for good organizing, how power is distributed, and heard from people actually doing the work.
This was a very interesting course. It gave me space to reflect on my own life, and on the way power works in cities and in organizing contexts.
I got to engage with organizing as a theory, and learn from real organizers as well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: the site visits and guest speakers. Weaknesses: writing assignment instructions could have been more clear and the reading load per week was a lot.

Professor Crumlish is very thoughtful and supportive, and creates a very warm academic space. At times I think it would be nice to have a more centralized trajectory, as you cover a lot of diverse ground in the class.

The strengths were how the course allowed us to really consider and appreciate New Haven beyond Yale. The course speakers were amazing and I gained an appreciation for what local organizing really looks like in the city. The readings were great, but there were too many of them. It was unrealistic to have us read so much because we really didn't have the time to understand and sit with the content. I would rather deeply understanding a few readings rather than having a superficial understanding of a lot of different ones. That being said, they were largely interesting readings, despite being overwhelming at times.
I think the readings are really interesting but I did feel confused on how some of the earlier readings related directly to organizing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would! I think it is a good intro to the concept of organizing.
If youre self motivated and interested in the topic, absolutely!
Yes. I think organizing is an important field and Professor Crumlish does a great job of helping studnets explore it.

extras.title: CSPC 350 01 - Power & Organizing in the City
